reviewText: I know that a lot of people hate RASEN, considering it to be a weak, confusing sequel to the magnificent RINGU. I'm in the minority of those who find it a refreshing departure from / expansion of the series. I like the idea of adding a genetic, science fiction angle to the sinister mix. I still enjoy RINGU, RINGU 2, and RINGU 0, but view RASEN as an alternate, inventive take on the Sadako saga...
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Ring" was a horror classic - tightly written, interesting, scary without being gross, and well-acted.  So of course I looked forward to seeing "Rasen."In contrast, "Rasen" is a badly-written and performed melodrama, boring, and not scary in the least.  Rather than a horror film, this is a tedious dramatic exercise that does not even rise to the level of a bad TV movie-of-the-week.  The rest of the "Ring" films ignore this movie, and I suggest that you do too.
Title: N/A

reviewText: It seems I enjoyed this sequel to the terrific "Ringu" more than the other reviewers on this page but still found it to be failure in the end.  Medical examiner Mitsuo Ando (Koichi Sato), grief-stricken over the recent death of his son and subsequent loss of his wife, conducts the autopsy on his friend Takayama (Hiroyuki Sanada), the psychic who died at the end of the first film.  He is drawn into the orbit of the Ring virus by a post-mortem communication from his old friend.  Much of this quietly dramatic film is very powerful, but the story becomes increasingly outlandish as it progresses.  Sato is outstanding, but he is undone by the screenplay and Joji Iida's direction.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Ringu" has become one of those seminal movies that helps define a genre. It's pure horror, creepy and intense without a single cheap thrill or scare.But don't expect anything so good from the (first) sequel. Though filmed and released at the same time as "Ringu," "Rasen" is its opposite in every way. It's not very scary. It's kind of silly. And worst of all, it crawls with a complete lack of tension right up to the freaky ending.Pathologist Mitsuo Ando (Koichi Sato) is startled when his good friend Ryuji (Hiroyuki Sanada) is brought in, mysteriously dead. During the autopsy, he finds a piece of paper inside Ryuji's stomach. Though Ando is sunk in grief for the loss of his son, who drowned recently, he is intrigued by whatever killed Ryuji and his family.He contacts Mai Takano (Miki Nakatani), Ryuji's assistant/girlfriend, and the two soon become close as they hunt for the secrets of the cursed videotape and the genetic encoding that is being transmitted through it. But when Mai watches the tape, something horrific happens -- and it returns the demon-woman Sadako to the world of the living...Based on Koji Suzuki's novel, "Rasen" was filmed and released at the same time as "Ringu," presumably so filmgoers could see what happened next right away. "Ringu" became a megahit, but the sequel was slow, unengaging and it demystified Sadako and the entire curse. No wonder they made a different sequel.Most of the plot is Ando meandering around looking for clues, having sad sex with Mai, researching, and crying. Director Jji Iida simply has no idea how to build tension and suspense. As a result, the pacing is glacial and the plot seems dense and hard to understand. The only really good scenes are at the finale, when Ando is faced with the ultimate devil's pact.Sato is a passable actor, but not a really good one; his performance as Ando is okay most of the time, but almost silly during the more emotional scenes. Nakatani isn't so great, however. She does a good job when playing the meek Mai, but when she's playing Sadako (as a hooker?) her performance is so campy that it's almost funny."Rasen" was an artistic and financial flop, and "Ring" completists are probably the only ones who will want to watch it. Not only is the story depressing, but the wasted potential is too.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Rasen was released in Japan alongside Ringu, and while Ringu became one of the most successful films in Japanese film history, Rasen was a flop. I'm not surprised.It begins where Ringu left off, after Ryuji's death. His friend from medical school, Mitsuo Ando, performs the autopsy, and declares that he died due to a myocardial infarction - a heart attack. They also find an ulceration in his throat, and a tumor which was on a blood vessel. When they culture the tumor, they find a virus similar to smallpox.Mitsuo speaks with Ryuji's ex-girlfriend, Mai, and hears about Sadako's videotape. Mitsuo hears that Reiko and her son Koichi have been in a fatal car accident; both died. At the scene of the accident, Reiko's boss, Yoshino, points out a video player in the car. After an autopsy, it is discovered that Koichi died before the crash.For no apparent reason, Yoshino pays a visit to Mitsuo, and gives him a picture of Sadako, Reiko's diary - which documents her work on Sadako - and a copy of the now infamous videotape. He also provides Mitsuo with a summation of the events, including Sadako's life and death at her father's hands, and her mother's suicide. He claims to be giving this information to Mitsuo because he wants to explore a scientific explanation.What they are able to determine is that a virus is at work - and that's where the film begins its downward spiral to silliness. It wants to be a horror movie and a medical thriller at the same time, but it can't have both. By trying to impose a medical or scientific reason behind the deaths, they instantly remove any aspect of credibility that they could have as a horror film. The fear of the unknown is one of the greatest fears, and once the film says, "Hey, this is how it's done," then more than half of the reason we were afraid at all disappears. Especially if we can qualify it scientifically.If that were the film's only failing, it might have survived and received a passing grade. What's surprising is that the film seemed to follow the book (from what I've been able to discover) with the overall theme that connects Ringu to Rasen. A theme that makes Sadako's madness seem reasoned and, frankly, that kind of ruins Ringu. If you decide to watch this, you may need to forget that this ever made its way to your DVD player to continue any appreciation you may have of Ringu.1 1/2 stars.

reviewText: ***WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS A HUUUUUUGE SPOILER. IF YOU HAVEN'T SEEN THE MOVIE, DON'T SCROLL DOWN ANY FURTHER! SO DON'T SAY I DIDN'T WARN YOU!***I own Rasen, and have seen it 7 times now. I did like it, but the fact that it waaaaay different from the first Ringu made me give it 2 stars.Mitsuko Ando is a surgeon whose friend Ryuji died (duh). He does an autopsy on him and finds a secret code hidden in his stomach (gross). He later learns from Mai Takano that it was because of a videotape and is later given the tape to him by a journalist as a "present". After watching the videotape, Sadako randomly shows up and starts having sex with him (NOT sexy at all). ***SPOIRLERS AHEAD*** One day, Mai dies, and is reborn... taken over by Sadako!*** END SPOILER***This is not bad, but could've been better.I could have given this 3 stars but something about it that wasnt in the first lowered the rating.**Not as good as the first, but still reccomended**
summary: Not as bad as people are saying, but still not great. *SPOILERS INSIDE*

reviewText: Rasen (Joji Iida, 1998)If you ever had any doubts about whether a director really has any influence in how well a movie turns out, think on this: Hideo Nakata took Koji Suzuki's very-good-but-not-great novel Ring and turned it into one of the best horror films of the last decade. Joji Iida took Koji Suzuki's great sequel, Spiral, and turned it into... this.Mitsuo Ando (Infection's Koichi Sato) is a medical examiner, suicidal over the death of his son and subsequent loss of his wife. As he's struggling with the idea of whether to end it all, he gets a call that Ryuji Takayama (The White Countess' Hiroyuki Sanada), an old classmate of his (and the hero of the first film), has just come into the morgue. Ando performs the autopsy, and finds some interesting anomalies that lead him into the mystery of the Ring, with the help of Takayama's erstwhile girlfriend Mai Takano (Miki Nakatani, soon to appear in the much-anticipated Silk). As they burrow deeper into the mystery, they find out that the ring virus has mutated...Where Nakata played up the creepiness of the atmosphere in Ring, Iida plays Spiral like a straight mystery. Which, in many ways, was the right decision; the book upon which it is based is less a horror novel than its predecessor. The problem is that Iida turns a fantastic, complex book, one of the finest mystery novels I've read in recent memory, into what seems like an extended episode of a generic TV police procedural; despite having hooked two of the actors from the original film, found a fine actor as the new protagonist, and being given a mind-bending storyline, there are quite a few points where you'll be wondering if you're not watching CSI: Shinjuku. Hideo Nakata, phone home. **

reviewText: "Rasen" is a great sequel to"Ringu", a great film that isitself a sequel to (althoughreleased before) another greatfilm "Ringu 0".Each of the three films are verydifferent and original in theirown right while keeping the commonthread of the plot and sensibilityin tact.I liked Rasen because it did notsimply continue the story of thevideotape and associated scares,but rather presents a substantialand extremely interesting plotprogression.There is another sequel to "Ringu","Ringu 2" that was released after"Rasen".It is good, but disconnected fromthe original sequel.This is a story that has plenty ofpotential to continue with "Rasen"as a point of departure rather than"Ringu 2", and I hope that it does.It is a very intelligent,interestingand scary ghost story.
